Award.AwardTitle: CSR: Small: Collaborative Research: Smartphone Enabled Social and Physical Compass System (SENSCOPS)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Smartphones equipped with powerful embedded sensors (e.g. accelerometers, GPS, microphones, etc.) can be used to monitor multiple dimensions of human behaviors including physical, mental, and social behaviors of wellbeing. In particular, such enhanced capabilities in mobile devices enable people to better manage their health. Existing mobile health applications mostly rely on manual data entry which may not be sufficient for certain population e.g. seniors and students with emotional behavioral disorders (EBD). This project aims to build a multimodal sensing system which provides continuous and efficient monitoring of users? activities using mobile phones and wearable sensors. Our system analyzes and correlates different sensor streams to infer certain behaviors as well as possible environmental factors that may trigger such behaviors. Furthermore, our system provides non-intrusive peer assisted localization technique that allows caregivers to track the whereabouts of monitored users. We also develop efficient schemes to infer higher layer information e.g. activity levels of monitored individuals; social relationships among monitored users. Additionally, the communities extracted from a mobile phone enabled social network in our system not only enable mobile healthcare systems but can also be exploited for securing certain components of the system (e.g., coping with clone attacks). Our system allows users to be monitored for their mental, cognitive, and physical well-being and can potentially reduce the cost for special need education as a result of increasing the productivity of teachers and caregivers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aims to build a multimodal sensing system which provides continuous and efficient monitoring of users' activities using mobile phones and wearable sensors. This system analyzes and correlates different sensor streams to infer certain behaviors as well as possible environmental factors that may trigger such behaviors. Furthermore, the system provides non-intrusive peer assisted localization technique that allows caregivers to track the whereabouts of monitored users. Efficient schemes are developed to infer higher layer information e.g. activity levels of monitored individuals; social relationships among monitored users. Additionally, the communities extracted from a mobile phone enabled social network in this system not only enable mobile healthcare systems but can also be exploited for securing certain components of the system.

This project results in multiple publications centered around three main areas: (1) Continuous efficient monitoring of users’ activities using mobile phones and wearable sensors. Accurate detection of certain behaviors and possible inferences of environments that trigger such behaviors by mining multimodal data streams from different sensors. (2) Non-intrusive peer assisted localization of users leveraging the integration of WiFi and acoustic ranging. (3) Secure fine-grained access of archived health related data by different parties and support of fuzzy keyword search capability.

(1) With sensors that can be easily attached to smartphones and the plurality of sensors embedded within smartphones, the collected sensing data can be mined for the understanding of people’s physical and mental health states. Information about users’ daily life activities and behaviors can further assist in the development of various emerging applications in the healthcare domain. We first exploit users’ unique physical traits extracted from smartphone-based sensor data, which are hard to forge, to mitigate user spoofing attacks in mobile healthcare systems. The basic idea is to utilize a user’s gait pattern because a person’s gait is often unique and can serve as a useful discriminator. A user may change his/her walking speeds, but the uniqueness embedded in each gait pattern remains unchanged. We further utilize the microphone on smartphones to perform fine-grained sleeping monitoring. We demonstrate that it is possible to achieve fine-grained non-invasive sleep monitoring at a minimal cost without the involvement of diagnostic devices by exploiting the off-the-shelf smartphone and its earphone.

(2) Human indoor localization was previously implemented using wireless sensor networks at the cost of sensing infrastructure deployment. Motivated by the high density of smartphones in public spaces, we develpo a robot-assisted localization system in which the low-cost Kinect sensor and smartphone-based acoustic relative ranging are used to localize moving human targets in indoor environments. We further design an extended Kalman filter (EKF) based dynamic positioning algorithm and integrate it with the acoustic relative ranging subsystem to provide real time localization of the moving human target. The localization performance is expected to comparable to recent indoor localization methods using WiFi signature maps, without the cost of deploying intensive sensing infrastructure.

(3) With the availability of affordable cloud computing technologies, people can efficiently collect, report, and manage their Personal Health Records (PHRs), which in turn improve the quality of healthcare services, and lower the healthcare cost.
